comment.author: 30369211@N00
comment._content: The NIAH lists the red-brick corner building noted above (37 Ashe Street) as 1896, so that's an earliest date. It could be a little later, as the OS 25" surveyed in 1898 does not show this building (with the corner cut at an angle for a doorway).

comment.author: 30369211@N00
comment._content: The YMCA building is from 1861, no help.

comment.author: 47290943@N03
comment._content:
[http://www.flickr.com/photos/91549360@N03] Who or what was The Palatine's Daughter?

Unusual name - Bovenizer! 56 of them in the 1901 census and 50 in 1911.
comment.authorname: National Library of Ireland on The Commons

comment.author: 91549360@N03
comment._content: The Palatines were German, mostly protestants. who, to avoid persecution by the French emigrated to Ireland, England and USA in early 1700s."The Palantine's daughter" was the theme tune for "The Riordans". www.irishpalatines.org/about/name.html The Wolfes were also descendants of the Palantines. By the way, "C" is for "Christian" not "Catholic". You will notice that there were no Catholics in the YMCA Tralee on census night 1901 :)

comment.author: 47290943@N03
comment._content: [http://www.flickr.com/photos/91549360@N03] Ooops, my apologies! Now fixed in the tags, thank you. And thanks for info on the Palatines.

comment.author: 69587809@N05
comment._content: In response to Danny M8 the lamp is the same, as the NLI picture begins at the short terrace leading to the Church of Ireland Anglican Episcopalian Church of St John the Evangelist in the Diocese of Ardfert and Aghadoe. Such a way of giving the denomination isn't very common but its broad appeal seems fitting to Ashe Street, Tralee. The street was known for being half Protestant and half Catholic and contains this lovely church, the Courthouse, prominent shops and old family homes. Those who once lived there included Austin Stack and the O'Donovan family, the ship owners who owned the Jeannie Johnston. [http://www.flickr.com/photos/mosskayree/9116985968/]

comment.author: 47290943@N03
comment._content: [http://www.flickr.com/photos/mosskayree] Hi Mossie! This is fascinating. Was it as "organised" as one side of the street was Protestant and the opposite side was Catholic, or was it both sides but different ends?
